key_points: Kyle Rittenhouse was found not guilty on all charges in connection to Kenosha shootings during protests last year.
The jury's verdict supports Rittenhouse's self-defense claim in the shootings that left two dead and one wounded.
Rittenhouse and his defense expressed relief and a desire to move on following the verdict.
Prosecutors and victims' families expressed disappointment, highlighting concerns over self-defense laws and accountability.
Political figures, including President Joe Biden and U.S. Sen. Ron Johnson, commented on the verdict, acknowledging the jury's decision.
The case has intensified debates over gun rights, self-defense, and racial justice in the United States.
Rittenhouse was 17 at the time of the shootings, which occurred during unrest following the police shooting of Jacob Blake Jr.
The defense argued Rittenhouse acted in self-defense against perceived threats from demonstrators.
Prosecutors portrayed Rittenhouse as a vigilante seeking conflict, questioning his self-defense claim.
The verdict has spurred calls for peaceful acceptance from both sides of the political spectrum.
spokespersons: Karen Bloom and John Huber (Anthony Huber's parents)
Joe Biden (President of the United States)
